text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- Anti-nuclear activists fail to get court ruling preventing use of Gorleben interim nuclear dump
- Terrorist group advertises in Internet
- DGB trade union federation puts forward 10-point plan on tax policy
- Bavarian retail workers agree pay deal with employers
- Opposition Social Democrats say labour ministry budget is house of cards
- Chancellor Kohl calls for more training places in industry
- German companies moving research activities abroad
HANDELSBLATT
- Opposition Social Democrats put forward tax plans
- Saxony state premier Biedenkopf accepts Jacques Santer's proposal for settlement of VW subsidy dispute
- Growth in building loans slows
- Industry pledges to create more training places
- Airbus to be profitable in 1996
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Social Democrats aim for drastic tax cuts
- Anti-nuclear activists fail to get court ruling preventing use of Gorleben interim nuclear dump
- Development budget cut by 342 million marks
- Boom in construction credits fades
- Former Mannesmann boss pays one million marks to end investigation
- Science minister wants to encourage German "silicon valleys"
DIE WELT
- Gorleben nuclear dump can continue to be used, court rules
- Science and education minister Ruettgers says 20,000 training places inindustry still needed this year
- SPD wants tax cuts for average earners
- EU wants tougher penalties for abuse of subsidies
- Farmers to get 1.2 billion marks for BSE losses
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 2609760
